Award.AwardTitle: GOALI: Diamond Wire Slicing of Crystalline Silicon Materials with Application to Manufacturing of High Quality Solar Cell Substrates

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
In fixed abrasive diamond wire slicing, very hard and brittle materials such as crystalline silicon and sapphire are cut into thin wafers utilizing a moving wire web consisting of thin steel wires coated with diamond abrasives. These wafers are used as substrates for photovoltaic solar cells and energy efficient lighting devices such as light emitting diodes. Although the fixed abrasive diamond wire slicing process can potentially offer higher production rates than existing semiconductor wafer slicing methods, scientific knowledge required for its cost-effective application and optimization is lacking. This Grant Opportunity for Academic Liaision with Industry (GOALI) award supports fundamental research that will yield the scientific knowledge needed to produce high quality photovoltaic solar silicon substrates with minimal mechanical damage. Since higher quality wafers are less prone to breakage during solar cell manufacture, the knowledge derived from this research will lead to lower solar cell production costs, which in turn will lead to lower solar energy costs. This will directly benefit the United States economy and the society at large. Knowledge derived from this research will also benefit other industries such as micro and optoelectronics where the diamond wire slicing process is used to cut other semiconductor and optical materials. The research involves the disciplines of advanced manufacturing, materials science, and mechanics. The project will engage students from diverse backgrounds including underrepresented groups, and will thereby contribute to educating the next generation of engineers in advanced manufacturing.

The research team will focus on understanding and minimizing the surface and sub-surface damage generated in diamond wire slicing of microstructurally-complex crystalline silicon materials used as substrates in photovoltaic solar cells. The specific objectives of the project are to understand and quantify the effects of diamond grit geometry, crystal orientation and defects (such as grain/twin boundaries, dislocation density variations), and diamond grit wear on the cutting mode (ductile vs. brittle), surface morphology, and sub-surface damage produced in diamond wire slicing of mono- and multi-crystalline solar silicon materials. Single grit diamond scribing experiments using diamond indenters with idealized shapes, crystal defect characterization as a function of crystal orientation, numerical modeling using the extended finite element modeling method, and lab-scale diamond wire slicing experiments will be used to investigate these effects. The findings from these investigations can be used to synthesize diamond wires with optimized grit shapes and wear behavior for use in the manufacture of high quality thin semiconductor wafers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objective of the project was to obtain fundamental knowledge of surface and subsurface damage, and wire wear produced in diamond wire slicing of single and multicrystalline silicon wafers used as solar cell substrates. The key outcomes of the project over the four-year period were as follows: 

(1) Knowledge of the influence of diamond abrasive shapes and microstructure defects in multi-crystalline silicon (grain boundaries and twins), and wire wear on the resulting surface and subsurface damage was gained. This work showed that abrasive shape can play a more significant role in the surface/subsurface damage than even crystal orientation, except in the immediate vicinity of the grain boundaries. Work the influence of wire wear showed that a new wire yielded more instances of subsurface lateral cracks in silicon wafers than wafers cut by the used wire. However, the used wire produced longer median cracks which resulted in lower mean fracture strength of the wafers.

(2) Knowledge of the wear of diamond when cutting multicrystalline silicon material was gained. The wear of diamond indenters in scribing mc-Si was found to be greater than in scribing monocrystalline silicon, confirming industrial reports of greater wire consumption when diamond wire sawing mc-Si. 

(3) Knowledge of the physico-chemical mechanism by which a water-based cutting fluid influences the ductile-to-brittle transition in cutting/scribing of silicon was gained. The water-based cutting fluid used in diamond wire sawing was found to enhance ductile mode cutting in diamond scribing of single crystal silicon compared to diamond scribing of the same material under ambient conditions. The critical depth of cut obtained in the presence of the cutting fluid was found to be greater than under ambient conditions. This result was explained using the theory of chemo-mechanical effect where increase in the surface charge carrier concentration on the silicon surface in the presence of the cutting fluid lowers the hardness of the surface and thereby promotes ductile mode cutting. Negative zeta potential measurements for the fluid-silicon interface support the theory.

(4) Knowledge of the influence of high scribing speeds on the phase transformation and material removal behavior of silicon and the underlying mechanisms. Specifically, the phase transformations of monocrystalline silicon during high-speed scribing were found to be dependent on the scribing speed. Si-IV phase with strong Raman intensity was detected in all scribed grooves. The Raman intensity ratio of a-Si to Si-IV in the scribed groove center presented an increasing trend with the scribing speed. The greater amount of a-Si formed at high scribing speed leads to increased material volume expansion and decreased residual depth of the scribed groove.

(5) A simplified new constitutive model of phase transformation in high speed scribing of silicon was developed and experimentally verified. This model enabled the influence of high-pressure induced phase transformation on material deformation behavior in scribing of silicon to be accurately simulated. 

(5) Five peer-reviewed journal papers, three refereed conference papers, and two non-refereed conference papers/presentations were disseminated to the research community.

(6) Two doctoral students, one post-doctoral researcher, and two undergraduate students, including one woman student, were trained by the project.
